summary: This document is an email chain from October 2021 regarding a federal court subpoena served on the Sacramento County Clerk/Recorder's office. The subpoena, issued by the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York in connection with a criminal trial, requests records. The correspondence involves county officials and a federal attorney discussing compliance procedures, including fee waivers and application forms.

persons.name: Andrew B. Graham
persons.context: County official corresponding about compliance with a federal subpoena for records, discussing procedures and fee waivers.

persons.name: Hermison, Jon
persons.context: Addressed in the initial email regarding the court subpoena served on the Sacramento County Clerk/Recorder's office.

persons.name: Colston, Noriko
persons.context: Copied on the initial email regarding the court subpoena served on the Sacramento County Clerk/Recorder's office.

connections.description: Graham forwards a subpoena-related email to Hermison, indicating a chain of communication within the county office regarding federal legal compliance.
Colston is copied on the initial subpoena inquiry email forwarded by Graham, showing shared responsibility for the matter.

events.title: Court Subpoena Issued
events.description: A subpoena is issued to the Sacramento County Clerk/Recorder, compelling testimony and production of records for a federal criminal case in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Subpoena Compliance Discussions
events.description: Email correspondence occurs regarding the procedures for complying with the federal subpoena, including fee waivers and application requirements.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: A federal subpoena was served on the Sacramento County Clerk/Recorder's office in connection with a criminal trial in the Southern District of New York.
The subpoena required the Clerk to appear in person to testify and produce records, prompting inquiries about whether physical appearance was mandatory.
County counsel determined that, as the subpoena was for a federal criminal case, the requested records should be provided at no fee.
Compliance required a completed vital record application, which could be signed but did not need to be notarized.
